Article.ArticleTitle: Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> alter the feeding efficiency of Acyrthosiphon pisum and Aphis craccivora via changes in foliar secondary metabolites.

AbstractText: Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> can affect aphid performance via altering plant nutrients, however, little is known about the role of plant secondary metabolites in this process, especially for aphids feeding behaviors. We determined the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> on the growth and phenolics of alfalfa (Medicago sativa) and feeding behaviors of the pea aphids (Acyrthosiphon pisum) and cowpea aphids (Aphis craccivora). Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> improved plant growth, but could not completely offset the negative effects of elevated O<sub>3</sub>. Elevated O<sub>3</sub> increased foliar genistin content at the vegetative stage, increased ferulic acid at the reproductive stage, and elevated CO<sub>2</sub> increased those at both stages. Simultaneously elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> increased foliar ferulic acid content at the reproductive stage and increased genistin content at both stages. For pea aphids, feeding efficiency was reduced under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> at the reproductive stage and decreased under elevated O<sub>3</sub> at the vegetative stage. For cowpea aphids, feeding efficiency was increased under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> at the vegetative stage and decreased under elevated O<sub>3</sub> at both stages. Simultaneously elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> decreased both aphids feeding efficiency. We concluded that CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> independently or interactively had different effects on two aphids feeding behaviors through altering foliar ferulic acid and genistin contents.
